On June 1, Merck & Company, with Public Service Electric & Gas, the Environmental Protection Agency and the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, unveiled a cooperative new emission reduction program. Your June 1 article minimized its significance.
The trade of emission reduction credits between P.S.E.&G. and Merck is a pioneering effort to develop a market-based, regional response to ozone problems in the Northeast.

New Jersey and the Northeast have been wrestling for years with high concentrations of ground-level ozone. Because the emissions that contribute to our ozone levels are dispersed widely into the atmosphere by every car, truck, factory or gas-powered lawnmower in operation, the problem defies traditional facility-by-facility solutions.

At Merck & Company, environmental protection remains a top priority. Since 1987, Merck has achieved a 69 percent reduction in releases and transfers of toxic chemicals worldwide, and we are on target to demonstrate a 90 percent reduction in 1996. DOROTHY BOWERS V.P., Environmental & Safety Policy Merck & Company Whitehouse Station, N.J., June 5, 1995
